document.title: Seiberg–Witten invariants on manifolds with Riemannian foliations of codimension 4

creator.contact: Département de Mathématiques, Université Libre de Bruxelles CP218, Boulevard du Triomphe, Bruxelles 1050, Belgique.
Département de Mathématiques, Université Libre de Bruxelles CP218, Boulevard du Triomphe, Bruxelles 1050, Belgique.

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: We define Seiberg–Witten equations on closed manifolds endowed with a Riemannian foliation of codimension 4. We show compactness of the moduli space when the manifold has dimension 5 or 6. We prove some vanishing and non-vanishing results and we highlight that the invariants may be used to distinguish different foliations on diffeomorphic manifolds.

document.acknowledgements: The first named author acknowledges travel support from the Communauté française de Belgique via an ARC and from the Belgian federal government via the PAI “DyGeSt”

The second named author was supported by an Aspirant grant from the F.R.S.-FNRS and acknowledges travel support from the Communauté française de Belgique via an ARC and from the Belgian federal government via the PAI “DyGeSt”.

para.p: Seiberg–Witten invariants are one of the main tools in the study of the differential topology of 4-manifolds. Since the foundational paper [60], a lot of work has been done to apply this theory to various aspects of three and four-dimensional geometry. A natural idea is to extend this framework to higher-dimensional manifolds. However the Seiberg–Witten equations then turn out to be overdetermined and one needs to assume that the manifold carries an additional geometric structure to extract useful information. For some results in this direction see [9, 15, 16, 23].

This article lays the groundwork for the case in which the higher-dimensional manifold admits a Riemannian foliation of codimension 4. For Yang–Mills instantons this has already been investigated by Wang [59] and, to a lesser extent, by Baraglia and Hekmati [6] in the more restrictive context of K-contact 5-manifolds. We would like to point out that, as opposed to these, we do not need to impose tautness of the foliation.

The main technical ingredient needed when extending to Riemannian foliations is the theory of basic transversally elliptic operators [20]. Most proofs become adaptations of standard arguments (see for instance [42, 43, 56] or the excellent survey of Li [39]) but we decided to include them nevertheless in order to stay self-contained and to emphasize the modifications which have to be done due to the presence of the mean curvature form of the foliation. We shall prove that, at least in dimension 5 and 6, the moduli space is compact. Furthermore, we give a non-vanishing result for transversally Kähler foliations and we highlight that the invariants may be used to distinguish different foliations on diffeomorphic manifolds. As the present work advanced, we became aware that J. Lee and A. Renner have work in progress on related results according to [59].

The plan of the article is the following: Sections 2, 3 and 4 are of an expository nature, setting up the notions of transverse structures and basic forms needed later on. We also establish a Weitzenböck formula as done in [25]. After these preliminaries, in Section 5 we write down a basic version of the Seiberg–Witten equations and in Section 6, we state a basic version of Sobolev estimates. In Section 7, we attack the crucial compactness property of the moduli space whilst Section 8 deals with other properties of the moduli space such as transversality and orientability and eventually gives the definition of basic Seiberg–Witten invariants. Applying the Weitzenböck formula, we deduce in Section 9 that, under some curvature assumptions, all invariants vanish. Interestingly enough, on non-taut foliations, the mean curvature form persists and hence gives a non-trivial difference with the classical four-dimensional case. On the other hand, as expected, the equations simplify considerably in the presence of a transversal Kähler structure. This allows us to prove in Section 10 a non-vanishing theorem for such foliations. The most well-known examples of transversally Kähler foliations being Sasakian manifolds, we conclude this article by taking a quick look at this class and their almost-Kähler counterpart: K-contact manifolds.

Finally we would like to point out that, besides Sasakian and K-contact 5-manifolds, there are many other interesting examples fitting in the framework of Riemannian foliations of codimension 4. Coisotropic submanifolds of Kähler manifolds [35, 45] (coisotropic A-branes), Vaisman as well as Calabi–Eckmann manifolds (see for instance [19]) all carry transversally Kähler foliations and are thus natural candidates for having non-trivial basic Seiberg–Witten invariants. We hope that this will inspire future work.

Acknowledgements: We warmly thank Ken Richardson for his invaluable help and for the proofs of Theorem 8 and Theorem 9. We are very grateful to Shuguang Wang for pointing out some mistakes in an earlier draft as well as letting us know about his work in progress with his student Andrew Renner on elliptic estimates for basic sections. We thank Yuri Kordyukov for very useful discussions and Tian-Jun Li for his interest in this work and comments. Finally, we thank Joel Fine for proposing the problem and his support.

Let M be a closed oriented smooth manifold of dimension =n+pq endowed with a Riemannian foliation F of codimension q and g a bundle-like metric on M [52]. The metric g gives an orthogonal splitting of the tangent bundle =⁢TM⊕⁢TF⁢TF⟂. Moreover we have a direct sum

Math.text: g = g _ (T * F) direct-sum g _ (T * F ^ perpendicular-to)

para.p: The normal bundle =Q⁢/⁢TMTF is identified with ⁢TF⟂ and so the metric g⁢TF⟂ induces a Riemannian metric gQ on Q. Since the metric g is bundle-like, the metric gQ satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(L _ X * g _ Q = 0, [for all ] * X element-of Gamma * T * F)

para.p: where L is the Lie derivative.

A bundle-like metric assures the existence of a unique torsion-free metric connection ∇T called the transverse Levi-Civita connection [41, 52, 55] on the normal bundle Q. Explicitly, let Dg be the Levi-Civita connection associated to the metric g and denote by :π⟶⁢TMQ the projection operator. We define ∇T on Q for ∈s⁢Γ(Q) by

Math.text: ((nabla ^ T) _ X)@(s) assign cases@(Array[[pi * closed-interval@(X, Y _ s), , X element-of Gamma * T * F], [pi * (D ^ g) _ X * Y _ s, , X element-of Gamma * Q]])

para.p: where ∈Ys⁢Γ(⁢TF⟂) corresponds to s via the identification ≅Q⁢TF⟂ The torsion-free condition and the Jacobi identity imply that ∇T is a leafwise flat connection i.e. its curvature RT satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(R ^ T * open-interval@(X, Y) assign ((nabla ^ T) _ X)@((nabla ^ T) _ Y) - ((nabla ^ T) _ Y)@((nabla ^ T) _ X) - (nabla ^ T) _ (closed-interval@(X, Y)) = 0, list@([for all ] * X, Y) element-of Gamma * T * F)

para.p: Actually, it can be shown that RT satisfies the stronger condition

Math.text: formulae@(iota _ X * R ^ T = 0, [for all ] * X element-of Gamma * T * F)

para.p: where ι is the contraction operator (see for example [28]). We define the transversal Ricci curvature :⁢RicT→⁢Γ(Q)⁢Γ(Q) and the transversal scalar curvature sT by

Math.text: formulae@(R * i * c ^ T * X assign (sum _ i)@(R ^ T * open-interval@(X, e _ i) * e _ i), s ^ T assign (sum _ i)@(g _ Q * open-interval@(R * i * c ^ T * e _ i, e _ i)))

para.p: where {e1,⋯,eq} is a local gQ-orthonormal frame of Q
The mean curvature vector field τ of F is defined by

Math.text: tau assign (sum _ i)@(pi * (D ^ g) _ xi _ i * xi _ i)

para.p: where {ξ1,⋯,ξp} is a local g⁢TF-orthonormal basis of ⁢TF The mean curvature form κ is the gQ-Riemannian dual of τ In other words, the mean curvature form is the trace of the second fundamental form of the foliation, which itself is symmetric by integrability of the distribution. A Riemannian foliation F is called taut if there exists a bundle-like metric for which =κ0.
The connection ∇T induces a connection, still denoted by ∇T, on the bundle ⁢ΛrQ∗ The basic sections ⁢ΓB(⁢ΛrQ∗) of ⁢ΛrQ∗ are then defined by

Math.text: Gamma _ B * Lambda ^ r * Q ^ ast assign conditional-set@(alpha element-of Gamma * Lambda ^ r * Q ^ ast, formulae@(((nabla ^ T) _ X)@(alpha) = 0, for-all@(X) element-of Gamma * T * F))

para.p: We can identify ⁢ΓB(⁢ΛrQ∗)⊂⁢Ωr(M):=⁢Γ(⁢ΛrT∗(M)) with the set of basic forms

Math.text: (Omega _ B) ^ r * M assign conditional-set@(alpha element-of Omega ^ r * M, formulae@(iota _ X * alpha = 0, formulae@(iota _ X * d * alpha = 0, for-all@(X) element-of Gamma * T * F)))

para.p: where d is the exterior derivative. We have the orthogonal decomposition [2]

Math.text: Omega ^ r * M = (Omega ^ r) _ B * M direct-sum (Omega ^ r) _ B * M ^ perpendicular-to

para.p: with respect to the C∞-Fréchet topology. In particular, the mean curvature form can be written as

Math.text: kappa = kappa _ B + kappa _ 0

para.p: where κB is the basic part and κ0 its orthogonal complement. Moreover, it is shown in [2] that the basic part of the mean curvature is closed, i.e. =⁢dκB0.
The metric gQ induces a transverse Hodge-star operator [55]

Math.text: overline@(ast) colon Lambda ^ r * Q ^ ast longrightarrow Lambda ^ (q - r) * Q ^ ast

para.p: Since the metric g is bundle-like, the transverse Hodge-star operator preserves basic forms

Math.text: overline@(ast) colon (Omega _ B) ^ r * M longrightarrow (Omega _ B) ^ (q - r) * M

para.p: It is related to the usual Hodge-star operator ∗ (induced by the metric g) via

Math.text: overline@(ast) * alpha = (- 1) ^ (p * (q - r)) ast (alpha and chi _ F)

para.p: where ∈α⁢ΩBr(M) and χF is the characteristic form of the foliation F [55]. We remark that we have the (basic) inner product in ⁢ΩrB(M)

Math.text: list@(alpha, beta) = (integral _ M)@(alpha) and overline@(ast) * beta and chi _ F

para.p: which is the restriction of the usual inner product on ⁢Ωr(M) to ⁢ΩBr(M) [55].
Note that the exterior derivative d preserves basic forms. Define

Math.text: d _ B assign evaluated-at@(d, (Omega _ B) ^ r * M) colon (Omega _ B) ^ r * M longrightarrow (Omega _ B) ^ (r + 1) * M

para.p: to be the restriction of d to basic forms. The resulting complex of basic forms is a subcomplex of the de Rham complex. Its cohomology is called the basic cohomology ⁢Hr(F) and can be interpreted as some kind of de Rham cohomology on the leaf space. It turns out that for Riemannian foliations on closed manifolds the basic cohomology groups are all finite-dimensional [21, 48].
In terms of the transverse Hodge-star operator, the adjoint operator δB of dB with respect to the (basic) inner product (1) is given by

Math.text: delta _ B * alpha = (- 1) ^ (q * (r + 1) + 1) * overline@(ast) * (d _ B - limit-from@(kappa _ B, and)) * overline@(ast) * alpha

para.p: where ∈α⁢ΩBr(M) In a local orthonormal basic frame {e1,⋯,eq} of ⁢Γ(Q) we can write

Math.text: d _ B = (sum _ i)@((e _ i) ^ (flat _ g _ Q)) and ((nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)@([ and its codifferential ] * delta _ B) = (- (sum _ i)@(iota _ e _ i * (nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)) + iota _ tau _ B

para.p: where =τB♭gQκB and ♭gQ denotes the gQ-Riemannian dual [2, 31]. One can then define the basic Laplacian

Math.text: Delta _ B assign d _ B * delta _ B + delta _ B * d _ B

para.p: Since the basic Laplacian is a basic transversally elliptic differential operator, it is a Fredholm operator with a finite index [20]. Moreover, using the Hodge decomposition of the basic Laplacian [32], we have that dim⁢Hr(F) is equal to the (finite) dimension of ΔB-harmonic basic r-forms. In general, ΔB does not commute with the transverse Hodge operator ¯∗ whereas when =κB0 we do have =⁢ΔB¯∗⁢¯∗ΔB

It is known that the space of bundle-like metrics on (M,F) is infinite dimensional [57]. It can be shown that any bundle-like metric can be deformed in the leaf directions leaving the transverse part untouched in such a way that the mean curvature form becomes basic [17]. Moreover, another suitable conformal change of the metric in the leaf direction will make κB, the basic component of κ, ΔB-harmonic [40].

We remark that, for any foliation F on a connected manifold, ⁢H1(F) is a subgroup of ⁢H1(M,R) [12, Proposition 2.4.1]. Moreover, if =κB0 then it readily follows from (3) that any basic ΔB-harmonic form is Δg-harmonic, where Δg is the (usual) Riemannian Laplacian associated to the metric g
When the foliation F has codimension =q4, we get a decomposition

Math.text: Lambda ^ 2 * Q ^ ast = Lambda ^ + * Q ^ * direct-sum Lambda ^ - * Q ^ *

para.p: where Λ± corresponds to the (±1)-eigenvalue under the action of the transverse Hodge-star operator ¯∗ Since the metric is bundle-like, there is an induced splitting of basic 2-forms

Math.text: (Omega ^ 2) _ B * M = (Omega ^ +) _ B * M direct-sum (Omega ^ -) _ B * M

para.p: Let ⁢H+(F) (resp. ⁢H-(F)) be the space of ΔB-harmonic ¯∗-self-dual (resp. ¯∗-anti-self-dual) basic 2-forms. When =κB0 we have ≅⁢H2(F)⊕⁢H+(F)⁢H-(F)
We can consider the following basic transversally elliptic linear operator

Choose a point ∈xM and a gQ-orthonormal basis {e1,⋯,eq} of Qx. The Clifford algebra of Qx is the complex algebra generated by 1 and e1,⋯,eq subject to the relations

Math.text: e _ i * e _ j + e _ j * e _ i = - 2 * delta _ (i * j)

para.p: Define the transverse Clifford bundle ⁢Cl(Q) over M as the Z2-graded vector bundle whose fiber at the point ∈xM is the Clifford algebra of Qx One can associate to this vector bundle the principal ⁢SO(q)-bundle of oriented gQ-orthonormal frames in Q The transverse Levi-Civita connection ∇T induces on ⁢Cl(Q) a leafwise flat connection ∇⁢Cl(Q) which is compatible with the multiplication preserving the Z2-grading.

A principal bundle →P(M,F) is called foliated [33, 41] if it is equipped with a lifted foliation FP invariant under the structure group action, transversal to the tangent space to the fiber and ⁢TFP projects isomorphically onto ⁢TF A vector bundle is foliated if its associated frame bundle is foliated.
A transverse Clifford module E is a complex vector bundle over M equipped with an action of ⁢Cl(Q), which we denote by ∙
A transverse Clifford module E is called self-adjoint if it is equipped with a Hermitian metric (⋅,⋅) such that the Clifford action is skew-adjoint at each point, i.e.

Math.text: formulae@(open-interval@(X bullet psi _ 1, psi _ 2) = - open-interval@(psi _ 1, X bullet psi _ 2), formulae@(for-all@(X) element-of list@(Gamma * C * l * Q, for-all@(psi _ 1)), psi _ 2 element-of Gamma * E))

para.p: A Clifford connection on E is a connection ∇E which is compatible with the Clifford action, i.e.

Math.text: formulae@((nabla ^ E)@(X bullet psi) = (nabla ^ (C * l * Q))@(X) bullet psi + X bullet (nabla ^ E)@(psi), formulae@(for-all@(X) element-of Gamma * C * l * Q, for-all@(psi) element-of Gamma * E))

para.p: Let E be a complex Hermitian foliated bundle over M such that E is a transverse Clifford module, self-adjoint and equipped with a Hermitian Clifford connection ∇E Moreover, we choose ∇E to be a basic connection which means that the connection and curvature forms of ∇E are (Lie algebra-valued) basic forms (this is always possible by a result of [33]). In this case, (E,∇E) is called a basic Clifford module bundle.
Define the operator :D⟶⁢Γ(E)⁢Γ(E) between smooth sections of E as the composition of the maps
In a local gQ-orthonormal frame {e1,⋯,eq} of Q we write

Math.text: D = (sum _ i)@(e _ i bullet (nabla ^ E) _ e _ i)

para.p: The operator D maps basic sections =⁢ΓB(E){∈s⁢Γ(E)|=∇EXs0,∈∀X⁢Γ(⁢TF)} to basic sections but it is not formally self-adjoint as D*=D-τ∙. Define the transverse Dirac operator [18, 25, 50] by
The operator D⁢tr is a self-adjoint, transversally elliptic differential operator but it is not basic. However, the operator

called basic Dirac operator [29], is a basic self-adjoint transversally elliptic differential operator. In particular, it is Fredholm. We emphasize that the basic Dirac operator DB depends on the choice of the bundle-like metric g, i.e. not only on gQ but also on the leafwise metric. Nevertheless, it turns out that each choice of bundle-like metric associated to gQ produces a new basic Dirac operator which is conjugate to the initial one. In particular, the dimension of the kernel of the basic Dirac operator is the same for any bundle-like metric associated to gQ [29].

Consider a basic Hermitian connection A on the (foliated) determinant line bundle of W Together with the transverse Levi-Civita connection ∇T, A induces a basic Clifford Hermitian connection ∇A on W. Let DBA be the basic Dirac operator associated to ∇A Then we get the following Weitzenböck formula (see [25]):

- ((1 / 2) * (d _ B * kappa _ B + delta _ B * kappa _ B)) bullet psi

Suppose that M is a closed oriented smooth manifold of dimension =n+p4 endowed with a Riemannian foliation F of codimension 4 and g a bundle-like metric on M. Suppose furthermore that the normal bundle Q is ⁢Spinc and fix a transverse ⁢Spinc-structure :ρ⟶⁢Clc(Q)⁢End(W) where W is a basic Clifford module bundle. Let L be the determinant line bundle of W We denote by

Math.text: K _ B * L = conditional-set@(A * [ Hermitian connection on ] * L, formulae@(L _ X * A = iota _ X * A = 0, for-all@(X) element-of Gamma * T * F))

para.p: the space of (smooth) Hermitian basic connections on L The space of basic connections on L is an affine space modeled on ⁢Γ(∧1Q∗,R) constant along the leaves which is the space ⁢Ω1B(M)
We define the basic Seiberg–Witten equations by

for the couple (A,ψ) with ∈A⁢KB(L) a basic Hermitian connection on L and ∈ψ⁢ΓB(W+) a basic section of ⁢Γ(W+). Here :σ⟶⁢ΓB(W+)⁢-1Ω+B(M) is the standard quadratic map, FA+ is the ¯∗-self-dual part of the curvature of A and DBA is the basic Dirac operator associated to the connection ∇A on W induced by the transverse Levi-Civita connection ∇T and A
The perturbed basic Seiberg–Witten equations additionally depend on a basic self-dual 2-form ∈μ⁢Ω+B(M):

The basic gauge group GB consists of gauge transformations ⁢C∞(M,⁢U(1)) of the ⁢U(1)-principle (foliated) bundle associated to L leaving invariant the lift ~F of the foliation F to the ⁢U(1)-principle bundle associated to L Hence, the group GB is identified with the (smooth) basic maps ⁢C∞B(M,S1). An element ∈uGB acts on a pair ∈(A,ψ)⁢×⁢KB(L)ΓB(W+) by :=(⁢u∗A,⁢uψ)(-A⁢2u-1du,⁢uψ) The basic gauge group GB fixes the space ⁢KB(L) and it is easy to see that the (perturbed) basic Seiberg–Witten equations are invariant under the action of GB. We will also consider the based basic gauge group :=G0{∈uG|=⁢u(x0)1} where a point ∈x0M is fixed. The action of GB is free except at pairs (A,0) with stabilizer given by constant maps. On the other hand, the action of G0 is always free. The group GB is actually the product of G0 with constant maps.
Define the basic Seiberg–Witten map

Math.text: Array[[s * w _ (list@(rho, mu)) colon absent, K _ B * L * Gamma _ B * W ^ +, longrightarrow, square-root@(- 1) * (Omega ^ +) _ B * M * Gamma _ B * W ^ -], [, open-interval@(A, psi), longmapsto, open-interval@((F _ A) ^ + - sigma * psi - square-root@(- 1) * mu, (D ^ A) _ B * psi)]]

para.p: We denote by :=mρ,μ{(A,ψ)|=⁢swρ,μ(A,ψ)0} and we define the moduli spaces

Math.text: formulae@(M _ (list@(rho, mu)) assign m _ (list@(rho, mu)) / G, (overline@(M)) _ (list@(rho, mu)) assign m _ (list@(rho, mu)) / G _ 0)

para.p: The space Mρ,μ is the quotient of ¯Mρ,μ by the action of constant maps.

Let ⁢Lp(⁢ΩB∗(M)) (resp. ⁢Lp(⁢ΓB(W+))) be the Lp-norm closure of the space of the smooth basic forms (resp. basic spinors). Let ⁢Wk,p(⁢ΩB∗(M)) (resp. ⁢Wk,p(⁢ΓB(W+))) be the closure of these spaces under the Sobolev (k,p)-norm. The norms of basic forms and basic spinors are taken with respect to ∇T and ∇A0 respectively, where ∈A0⁢KB(L) is a smooth reference connection. We denote the Sobolev norms (resp. the Lp-norm) by ∥⋅∥k,p (resp. ∥⋅∥Lp).

To ease the notations, we let Wk,p stand for ⁢Wk,p(⁢ΩB∗(M)) or ⁢Wk,p(⁢ΓB(W+)) unless it is necessary to specify the space. The basic Sobolev spaces Wk,p satisfy the basic Sobolev embedding theorem (see [8, Lemma 3.7] when =p2). More precisely, if we have integers l, q such that 0⩽l⩽k and -lnq⩽-knp<l with n the dimension of the manifold M, then there is a continuous inclusion

Math.text: W ^ (list@(k, p)) hookrightarrow W ^ (list@(l, q))

para.p: Moreover, for <γ-knp

Math.text: W ^ (list@(k, p)) hookrightarrow C ^ gamma

para.p: where Cγ stands for the sections of regularity Cγ.
We also get a basic Rellich theorem (see [32, Proposition 4.5]) which states that the inclusion

Math.text: W ^ (list@(k + 1, 2)) hookrightarrow W ^ (list@(k, 2))

para.p: is compact for all k whenever >n2.
Finally, we get a basic Sobolev multiplication theorem (the standard proof [1, Theorem 4.39] works for the basic case) which says the following when 0⩽l⩽k:
Above the borderline: if >-knp0 and ⩾-knp-lnq then we have a continuous map

Math.text: W ^ (list@(k, p)) * W ^ (list@(l, q)) longrightarrow W ^ (list@(l, q))

para.p: Under the borderline: if <-knp0 and <-lnq0 then we have a continuous map

para.p: with 0⩽m⩽l and r such that 0<-+-+mn1pkn1qln⩽1r⩽1.
On the borderline: if =-knp0 and ⩽-lnq0 then we have a continuous map

Math.text: (W ^ (list@(k, p)) intersection L ^ infinity) * (W ^ (list@(l, q)) intersection L ^ infinity) longrightarrow W ^ (list@(l, q)) intersection L ^ infinity

para.p: If <-lnq0 then we can improve this to a continuous map

para.p: We can define =G+k1,pB⁢Wk,p(∩⁢ΓB(⁢End(W))⁢C0B(M,S1)) whenever >knp. Later on, when dealing with transversality issues of the moduli space, we will need a unique continuation property for basic transversally elliptic operators. So let :P→⁢ΓB(E1)⁢ΓB(E2) be a basic transversally elliptic operator with E1 and E2 two vector bundles over M and ⁢ΓB(E1), ⁢ΓB(E2) the corresponding spaces of basic sections. Denote by P∗ the (basic) adjoint of P. Ken Richardson kindly communicated to us the proof of the following two theorems.

p.text: Let M be a connected manifold endowed with a Riemannian foliation. Then, any basic transversally elliptic operator satisfies the unique continuation property.

para.p: The transversally elliptic operator ⁢P∗P is the restriction to ⁢ΓB(E1) of a truly elliptic operator on ⁢Γ(E1). By standard theory, the truly elliptic operator satisfies the unique continuation property. Now, suppose that =⁢Ps0 with s a basic section identically zero near a leaf closure. In particular, it is zero in a neighborhood of a point of the leaf closure. Then the unique continuation property for ⁢P∗P implies that s is identically zero. ∎
We have the following regularity result (L2-estimates) which will be crucial for the compactness of the moduli space.

p.text: Let :P→⁢ΓB(E1)⁢ΓB(E2) be a basic transversally elliptic operator of order 1. Then, for every ∈s⁢W+k1,2(⁢ΓB(E1)) there are constants c1,c2 (depending on k) such that

Math.text: (norm@(s)) _ (list@(k + 1, 2)) less= c _ 1 * (norm@(P * s)) _ (list@(k, 2)) + c _ 2 * (norm@(s)) _ (list@(k, 2))

p.text: Moreover, if s is L2-orthogonal to the kernel of P then =c20.

Then it follows from the ellipticity and self-adjointness of Bi that, for a section ∈si⁢ΓB(Ei) (=i1,2), there are constants c1,c2,c3,c4 such that

Math.text: formulae@(((norm@(s _ i)) ^ 2) _ (list@(k, 2)) less= c _ 1 * list@((D _ i) ^ k * s _ i, s _ i) + c _ 2 * ((norm@(s _ i)) ^ 2) _ (L ^ 2), ((norm@(s _ i)) ^ 2) _ (list@(k, 2)) >= c _ 3 * list@((D _ i) ^ k * s _ i, s _ i) + c _ 4 * ((norm@(s _ i)) ^ 2) _ (L ^ 2))

c _ 1 * list@(P ^ ast * (D _ 2) ^ k * P * s, s)

Another possible way to derive the above L2-estimates, suggested to us by Yuri Kordyukov, is to use the existence of a parametrix for a transversally elliptic differential operator [36, Proposition 10]. Then Theorem 9 shall follow if one shows that the composition of the parametrix with the projection on the space of the basic sections is a smoothing operator.

Finally, to prove compactness of the moduli space, we shall use a bootstrapping argument involving Lp-estimates for the basic Dirac operator. Hence, we need to see that the Dirac operator DM on the manifold M restricted to the basic sections of the basic Clifford module bundle (W,∇W) is the basic Dirac operator modulo an operator of zero order. We then get for free the Lp-estimates for the basic Dirac operator.

p.text: Let ∈ψ⁢Wk,p(⁢ΓB(W)) with ⩾k0 and ⩾p2. Then there exist constants c3, c4 depending only on k,p such that

para.p: The aim of this section is to show compactness of the moduli space when the manifold endowed with the Riemannian foliation of codimension 4 has dimension 5 or 6. We follow closely the excellent exposition in [39]. Throughout this section all the constants depend on the metric g, the perturbation μ in (7) and the transverse ⁢Spinc-structure.
We shall first prove an a priori pointwise bound on the basic spinor ψ and on the curvature FA+. The next lemma follows from a simple computation.

p.text: Let f be a basic function and {e1,⋯,eq} a local gQ-orthonormal basic frame of Q. Then

Math.text: Delta _ B * f = (- (sum _ i)@(((nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)@(((nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)@(f)))) + (sum _ i)@(((nabla ^ T) _ (((nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)@(e _ i)))@(f)) + ((nabla ^ T) _ tau _ B)@(f)

We can now combine the basic Kato inequality with the Weitzenböck formula to get the desired a priori pointwise estimates.

para.p: Let x0 be a point where |ψ|2 is maximal. At the point x0, we pick normal coordinates such that the mean curvature vector field =τx00 and thus =⁢(⁢Δgf)(x0)⁢(⁢ΔBf)(x0) for any basic function f, where Δg is the (usual) Riemannian Laplacian with respect to the metric g. Then, either, >|ψ|20 at x0 and

Math.text: 0 less= ((((- s ^ T / 2 - (1 / 2) * (absolute-value@(kappa _ B)) ^ 2) + delta _ B * kappa _ B) - (1 / 2) * (absolute-value@(psi)) ^ 2) + 2 * absolute-value@(mu)) * (absolute-value@(psi)) ^ 2

We would like to show that the L2-bound on the curvature FA+ gives an W1,2-bound on the connection A if written in an appropriate gauge. For the reader’s convenience, we write out Uhlenbeck’s gauge fixing Lemma as done in [42]. For this purpose, we fix a smooth reference connection ∈A0⁢KB(L).

p.text: For any ⩾k0 there exist constants c1, c2 depending only on k, A0 such that for any ∈A⁢Wk,2(⁢KB(L)) there exists a gauge transformation ∈u⁢W+k1,2(GB) such that =⁢u∗A+A0⁢-1α where ∈α⁢Wk,2(⁢Ω1B(M)) satisfies both the Coulomb gauge condition =⁢δBα0 and the estimate

Math.text: (norm@(alpha)) _ (list@(k + 1, 2)) less= c _ 1 * (norm@((F _ A) ^ +)) _ (list@(k, 2)) + c _ 2

para.p: Let =A+A0⁢-1α0 The basic function ⁢δBα0 is L2-orthogonal to the constant functions. We denote by GB the basic Green operator (associated to the basic Laplacian ΔB) and define =u0exp(⁢-12GB(⁢δBα0)) Then =⁢u0∗A-+A0⁢-1α0⁢-1dGB(⁢δBα0). Obviously,

Math.text: delta _ B * (alpha _ 0 - d * G _ B * delta _ B * alpha _ 0) = delta _ B * alpha _ 0 - delta _ B * d * G _ B * delta _ B * alpha _ 0 = 0.

para.p: To get the estimate, recall that the operator :⊕δBdB+→⁢ΩB1(M)⊕⁢ΩB0(M)⁢ΩB+(M) is a basic transversally elliptic operator. Hence we can apply the basic Hodge decomposition

Math.text: alpha = alpha _ H + delta _ B * beta + d _ B * f

para.p: where ∈αHker(⊕δBdB+), ∈β⁢ΩB+(M) and ∈f⁢ΩB0(M). The basic gauge fixing condition =⁢δBα0 implies that the last term ⁢dBf vanishes and thus =α+αH⁢δBβ. Moreover,

Math.text: (F _ A) ^ + = (F _ A _ 0) ^ + + square-root@(- 1) * (d _ B) ^ + * alpha = (F _ A _ 0) ^ + + square-root@(- 1) * (d _ B) ^ + * delta _ B * beta = (F _ A _ 0) ^ + + square-root@(- 1) * (delta _ B + (d _ B) ^ +) * delta _ B * beta

We would like to turn the W2,2-bound on α and the C0-bound on ψ into C∞-bounds. This is done by bootstrapping. To ease the reading, we separate the bootstrapping in two regions: the initial launching phase which depends crucially on the dimension of the manifold and the stable bootstrapping region where we can use Sobolev multiplication above the borderline.

We shall increment the regularity of α and ψ repeatedly by alternating elliptic regularity with Sobolev multiplication. Thus we need the Sobolev multiplication to preserve Wk,2 objects in the sense that →×Wk,2Wk,2Wk,2. This is true if we are above the borderline >kn2, where n is the dimension of the manifold M. In other words, the number of weak derivatives we need to bound before entering the stable bootstrapping region increases with the dimension of the manifold M.

subsubsection.title: 7.4.4Launching the bootstrapping in dimension 7 or higher
subsubsection.toctitle: 7.4.4Launching the bootstrapping in dimension 7 or higher

para.p: We have not been able to launch the bootstrapping in dimension 7 or higher. Hence we cannot conclude whether the moduli space is compact or not. Indeed, to use the same method, one would need either a W2,p-bound or a Wk,2-bound on α. However, the first would require Lp-estimates for the operator ⊕δBdB+ (which we have not been able to prove) whereas the second seems out of reach as the Weitzenböck formula cannot help anymore to give higher a priori derivative bounds.

The foliation is zero-dimensional and we actually find back standard Seiberg–Witten theory. So the moduli space is compact. Still, we would like to point out one phenomenon. Using Sobolev multiplication on the borderline along with the C0-bound on ψ (as done in the proof of dimension 6) we only need an W1,2-bound on α instead of the W2,2-bound to launch. We believe this proof to have an interest in its own right because all the elliptic estimates needed become L2 except for a unique L4-estimate for the Dirac operator. This brings to light the very mild non-linearity of the Seiberg–Witten equations.
We finally have all the ingredients to prove the main result of this section, compactness of the moduli space Mρ,μ.

p.text: Let M be a closed oriented smooth manifold of dimension 5 or 6 endowed with a Riemannian foliation of codimension 4. For any ⁢Spinc-structure ρ and any perturbation μ the moduli space Mρ,μ is compact in the C∞-topology.

para.p: To prove compactness we need to show that any sequence of Seiberg–Witten solutions (ψi,Ai) admits a converging subsequence. By the previous results, any solution (ψi,Ai) lies automatically in ×Wk,2Wk,2 for all k if written in the appropriate gauge. By the basic Rellich theorem, any W+k1,2-bounded sequence has a subsequence which converges in Wk,2. Hence, for any k there is a subsequence converging in Wk,2. The basic Sobolev embedding theorem tells us that the subsequence converges in Cl for all l, i.e. in C∞. ∎
The following Lemma, taken from [39], shows that the moduli space Mρ,μ is also separated.

p.text: The basic Seiberg–Witten complex is transversally elliptic.

para.p: The symbol of a differential operator only depends on the highest order derivatives. The simplified complex splits as the direct sum of two complexes
Both complexes are transversally elliptic. ∎

The standard construction of the determinant line bundle of a family of elliptic operators can be extended to a family of Fredholm operators (see for instance [38]). The operators DAB and ⊕δBdB+ are Fredholm. The determinant line bundle of the basic Seiberg–Witten complex is then isomorphic to the tensor product of the determinant line bundle of DAB and ⊕δBdB+ The complex multiplication generates a nowhere vanishing section trivializing the determinant line bundle of DAB while a choice of orientation of ker(⊕δBdB+) and ⁢coker(⊕δBdB+) (see Proposition 3) trivializes the determinant line bundle of ⊕δBdB+ Hence, the top exterior power of the tangent to the moduli space is trivialized inducing an orientation on the moduli space.

p.text: Suppose that the Riemannian foliation F has totally umbilical leaves and =κκB is basic. Moreover, suppose that g has constant curvature c such that +⁢12c⁢+⁢p(-p1)1p2|κB|2|A|2 is positive. Then all ⁢SW(F,ρ) vanish. In particular, if c is positive, then all ⁢SW(F,ρ) vanish.

para.p: Let R be the curvature of the Levi-Civita connection Dg and ^R be the curvature of the induced connection along the leaves :=^D-DgT. Then we have the following formula (see [27, 44] paying attention to signs in the definition of the curvature tensor)

Consider a Riemannian manifold with constant curvature which admits a p-dimensional foliation with bundle-like metric g and totally umbilical leaves with respect to g. A result of [4, Proposition 2.4] states that if ⩾p2, then κ is basic and ≡A0.

para.p: Let M be a closed manifold with a Riemannian foliation F of even codimension q and g a bundle-like metric on M inducing the metric gQ on the normal bundle Q. Suppose that Q is equipped with a transverse Hermitian structure (gQ,J), i.e. an endomorphism :J⟶QQ such that =J2-⁢IdQ and gQ(⋅,⋅)=gQ(J⋅,J⋅). Then the complexified bundle splits as =⊗QC⊕Q1,0Q0,1 where Q1,0 (resp. Q0,1) corresponds to the eigenvalue -1 (resp. --1). Similarly J induces a splitting of the complexification of Q∗:

Math.text: Q ^ ast tensor-product C = Lambda ^ (list@(1, 0)) * Q ^ ast direct-sum Lambda ^ (list@(0, 1)) * Q ^ ast

para.p: where ⁢Λ1,0Q∗ (resp. ⁢Λ0,1Q∗) is the annihilator of Q0,1 (resp. Q1,0). More generally, the bundle ⁢ΛrB(M,C) of complex basic forms splits as

Math.text: (Lambda ^ r) _ B * open-interval@(M, C) = (direct-sum _ (i + j = r))@((Lambda ^ (list@(i, j))) _ B * M)

para.p: We can define the basic Dolbeault operators :∂B→⁢Ωp,qB(M)⁢Ω+p1,qB(M) and :¯∂B→⁢Ωp,qB(M)⁢Ωp,+q1B(M) by

Math.text: formulae@((partial-differential _ B)@(alpha) assign (d _ B * alpha) ^ (list@(p + 1, q)), (overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * alpha assign (d _ B * alpha) ^ (list@(p, q + 1)))

para.p: The transverse Levi-Civita connection ∇T induces canonical Hermitian connections ∇1,0 and ∇0,1 on Q1,0 and Q0,1 respectively. In a local gQ-orthonormal frame {e1,⋯,eq} of Q we can then write

Math.text: formulae@(partial-differential _ B = (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ q)@((e _ i + square-root@(- 1) * J * e _ i) ^ flat) and (nabla ^ T) _ e _ i, (overline@(partial-differential)) _ B = (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ q)@((e _ i - square-root@(- 1) * J * e _ i) ^ flat) and (nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)

para.p: where ♭ denotes the (gQ,J)-Hermitian dual. If we denote by ∂B∗, ¯∂B∗ the basic adjoints of ∂B, ¯∂B with respect to the Hermitian inner product, then

Math.text: Array[[(partial-differential _ B) ^ ast = (- (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ q)@(iota _ (e _ i - square-root@(- 1) * J * e _ i) * (nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)) + (1 / 2) * iota _ (tau _ B - square-root@(- 1) * J * tau _ B)], [((overline@(partial-differential)) _ B) ^ ast = (- (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ q)@(iota _ (e _ i + square-root@(- 1) * J * e _ i) * (nabla ^ T) _ e _ i)) + (1 / 2) * iota _ (tau _ B + square-root@(- 1) * J * tau _ B)]]

para.p: Consider the self-adjoint transverse Clifford module

Math.text: Lambda ^ (list@(0, star)) * Q ^ * = Lambda ^ (list@(0, even)) * Q ^ ast direct-sum Lambda ^ (list@(0, odd)) * Q ^ ast

The bundle ∧0,⋆Q* turns out to be a basic Clifford module bundle and one can then define a basic Dirac operator on it (see for instance [37]).

A transverse Kähler structure (gQ,J,ω) is given by a transverse Hermitian structure (gQ,J) such that ω, the pull-back of gQ(J⋅,⋅) to M, is closed. Consider the canonical ⁢Spinc-structure ρ⁢can induced by the complex structure :J→QQ on the normal bundle Q. Its determinant bundle is ⁢Λ0,q2Q∗ [49]. Let ρ be a ⁢Spinc-structure over the normal bundle Q with determinant line bundle ⊗⁢Λ0,q2Q∗E2 with E a (foliated) complex Hermitian line bundle over M The spinor bundle W can then be identified with ⊗⁢Λ0,⋆Q∗E Moreover,

Math.text: formulae@(W ^ + approximately-equals (Lambda ^ (list@(0, e * v * e * n)) * Q ^ ast) tensor-product E, W ^ - approximately-equals (Lambda ^ (list@(0, o * d * d)) * Q ^ ast) tensor-product E)

para.p: Let A0 be the canonical connection on ⁢Λ0,⁢evenQ∗ induced by ∇T and fix a basic Hermitian connection A on E. The connections A0 and A induce a connection A on W+ The formulae (14) and (15) hold for the basic sections of W+ using the induced connection ∇A and the Cauchy–Riemann operator ¯∂A induced by A

para.p: We now take a closer look to the basic Seiberg–Witten equations. We use the argument of [10, Lemme 1] to deduce that, for a generic ∈μ⁢Ω+B(M) and when ⩾dimP+1 (recall that P+ is given by (12)), the ⁢SW(F,ρ) invariants associated to the moduli space of the system of equations

Moreover, we deduce from the basic unique continuation theorem (Theorem 8) that either ≡α0 and/or ≡β0. We can now use the splitted system of equations to write down a non-vanishing theorem just as it is done for Kähler surfaces. But first, we need the following Weitzenböck formula:

p.text: Let M be a closed manifold of dimension 5 or 6 equipped with a Riemannian foliation F of codimension 4, a bundle-like metric g and a transverse Kähler structure (gQ,J,ω) with ⩾dimP+2. Then =⁢SW(F,ρ⁢can)±1.

para.p: The canonical ⁢Spinc-structure ρ⁢can corresponds to the case where =EC is the trivial line bundle. We pick the perturbation =⁢-1μ-FA0+⁢-14ω.
First, we claim that α cannot vanish. Indeed, the last equation of (19) reads

Math.text: ((d _ B) ^ + * A) ^ (list@(1, 1)) = - (square-root@(- 1) / 4) * ((1 - (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2) + (absolute-value@(beta)) ^ 2) * omega

para.p: where ∈A⁢-1ΩB1(M) Let ∈θ⁢ΓB(⁢Λ0,0Q∗) be a non zero holomorphic section with respect to the holomorphic connection A, i.e. =⁢¯∂Aθ0. The existence of θ is a consequence of Theorem 9. Actually, θ is a nowhere vanishing section since the line bundle is trivial. Then, =A0,1-⁢¯∂Blog|θ|2 and thus =A⁢12(⁢(-∂B¯∂B)log|θ|2) In particular, ⁢dBA=⁢¯∂B∂B(log|θ|2)=⁢-12dBJdB(log|θ|2) The inner product with ω gives

para.p: We choose the bundle-like metric g such that κB is ΔB-harmonic (see Remark 1). We obtain

Math.text: list@(((d ^ +) _ B * A) ^ (list@(1, 1)), omega) = 0.

para.p: Using (20), this implies that =∫M⁢(+-1|α|2|β|2)vg0 and thus α cannot vanish. We deduce that ≡β0. Now, Lemma 37 and (20) imply that

Math.text: ((1 / 2) * (integral _ M)@((absolute-value@(d _ A * alpha)) ^ 2 * v _ g) - (1 / 4) * (integral _ M)@((1 - (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2) * (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2 * v _ g)) + (square-root@(- 1) / 2) * (integral _ M)@(open-interval@(((nabla ^ A) _ (J * tau _ B))@(alpha), alpha) * v _ g) = 0.

para.p: As =∫M⁢(-1|α|2)vg0 we can rewrite this as

Math.text: (1 / 2) * (integral _ M)@((absolute-value@(d _ A * alpha)) ^ 2 * v _ g) + (1 / 4) * (integral _ M)@((1 - (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2) ^ 2 * v _ g) + (square-root@(- 1) / 2) * Im * (integral _ M)@(open-interval@(((nabla ^ A) _ (J * tau _ B))@(alpha), alpha) * v _ g) = 0.

para.p: Recall that =⁢¯∂Aα0 and so =∇A⁢JτBα⁢-1∇AτBα. In particular,

Math.text: Im * open-interval@(((nabla ^ A) _ (J * tau _ B))@(alpha), alpha) = square-root@(- 1) * Re * open-interval@(((nabla ^ A) _ tau _ B)@(alpha), alpha) = (square-root@(- 1) / 2) * d * (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2 * tau _ B

para.p: It follows that

Math.text: (integral _ M)@(Im * open-interval@(((nabla ^ A) _ (J * tau _ B))@(alpha), alpha) * v _ g) = ((- square-root@(- 1)) / 2) * (integral _ M)@(d * (absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2 * tau _ B * v _ g) = (square-root@(- 1) / 2) * (integral _ M)@((absolute-value@(alpha)) ^ 2 * delta _ B * tau _ B * v _ g) = 0.

para.p: From (21), we conclude that =⁢dAα0 and ≡|α|1. This implies that A=⁢12(⁢(-∂B¯∂B)log|α|2)=0 and so A is the exterior derivative d. Hence, α is a constant and after a gauge transformation, ≡α1.

It remains to be proven that the moduli space is smooth at this point. The problem is reduced to check that the kernel of ⁢dswρ⁢can,μ(d,(1,0)) is trivial. We are looking to the solutions (⁢-1λ,(ϕ0,ϕ1)) of the system

Math.text: (d ^ +) _ B * square-root@(- 1) * lambda - (overline@(phi)) _ 1 - phi _ 1 - square-root@(- 1) * phi _ 0 * omega = 0
(d ^ +) _ B * square-root@(- 1) * lambda - (overline@(phi)) _ 1 - phi _ 1 - square-root@(- 1) * phi _ 0 * omega
(overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * phi _ 0 + ((overline@(partial-differential)) ^ ast) _ B * phi _ 1 + (square-root@(- 1) * lambda) ^ (list@(0, 1)) = 0.
(overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * phi _ 0 + ((overline@(partial-differential)) ^ ast) _ B * phi _ 1 + (square-root@(- 1) * lambda) ^ (list@(0, 1))

para.p: By gauge transformation, we are assuming here that ϕ0 is real. We apply ¯∂B to the equation (23) to obtain

Math.text: (overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * ((overline@(partial-differential)) ^ ast) _ B * phi _ 1 + (overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * (square-root@(- 1) * lambda) ^ (list@(0, 1)) = 0

para.p: while from the equation (22) we have =⁢¯∂B(⁢-1λ)0,1ϕ1 Hence,

Math.text: (overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * ((overline@(partial-differential)) ^ ast) _ B * phi _ 1 + phi _ 1 = 0.

para.p: Coupling with ϕ1 and integrating, we deduce that =ϕ10. Now, the system becomes

Math.text: (1 / 2) * open-interval@(d _ B * lambda, omega) - phi _ 0 = 0
(1 / 2) * open-interval@(d _ B * lambda, omega) - phi _ 0
(overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * phi _ 0 + (square-root@(- 1) * lambda) ^ (list@(0, 1)) = 0.
(overline@(partial-differential)) _ B * phi _ 0 + (square-root@(- 1) * lambda) ^ (list@(0, 1))

para.p: The equation (25) implies that =⁢dBλ⁢2-1¯∂B∂Bϕ0 Plugging this in equation (24) and by a simple computation we obtain that =-+-⁢ΔBϕ0∇TτBϕ0ϕ00. Coupling with ϕ0 and integrating, we obtain

Math.text: ((integral _ M - (absolute-value@(d _ B * phi _ 0)) ^ 2) + (1 / 2) * d _ B * (absolute-value@(phi _ 0)) ^ 2 * tau _ B) - (absolute-value@(phi _ 0)) ^ 2 = 0.

para.p: However, as =⁢δBτB0 we conclude that =ϕ00 and thus =λ0.∎
A similar non-vanishing result should hold when the transverse structure (gQ,J,ω) is almost-Kähler i.e. when (gQ,J) is almost-Hermitian and ω is closed [58].

In this last section, we take a closer look at some particular class of manifolds with Riemannian foliations: Sasakian manifolds and more generally K-contact manifolds. Let (M,η) be a contact manifold of dimension +⁢2n1, where η is the contact 1-form satisfying ≠∧η(⁢dη)n0 at every point of M. The Reeb vector field ∈ξ⁢Γ(⁢TM) is uniquely determined by

Math.text: formulae@(eta * xi = 1, iota _ xi * d * eta = 0.)

para.p: The corresponding foliation Fξ is the distribution ⊂⁢Rξ⁢TM
A K-contact structure (η,ξ,Φ,g) on M consists of a contact form η with Reeb field ξ together with an endomorphism :Φ→⁢TM⁢TM satisfying

Math.text: formulae@(Phi ^ 2 = (- Id _ (T * M)) + xi tensor-product eta, L _ xi * Phi = 0.)

para.p: We also require the following compatibility conditions with η:

Math.tex: d\eta(\Phi X,\Phi Y)=d\eta(X,Y),\quad d\eta(Z,\Phi Z)>0\quad\forall X,Y\in TM,% Z\in\ker(\eta)\setminus\{0\}.
Math.text: formulae@(d * eta * open-interval@(Phi * X, Phi * Y) = d * eta * open-interval@(X, Y), formulae@(d * eta * open-interval@(Z, Phi * Z) > list@(0, for-all@(X)), formulae@(Y element-of T * M, Z element-of kernel@(eta) set-minus set@(0))))

para.p: This defines a Riemannian metric on M given by

Math.text: g * open-interval@(X, Y) = d * eta * open-interval@(X, Phi * Y) + eta * X * eta * Y

para.p: For a K-contact structure (η,ξ,Φ,g), the foliation Fξ is Riemannian and the leaves of Fξ are geodesics. In particular, the foliation is taut.
A Sasakian structure is a K-contact structure (η,ξ,Φ,g) satisfying the integrability condition

Math.text: formulae@((D ^ g) _ X * Phi = xi tensor-product X ^ (flat _ g) - X tensor-product eta, for-all@(X) element-of Gamma * T * M)

para.p: where Dg is the Levi-Civita connection.

Clearly, a K-contact (resp. Sasakian) structure induces an almost-Kähler (resp. Kähler) structure on the normal bundle Q In particular, Φ induces an almost-complex (resp. complex) structure J on Q and hence a canonical ⁢Spinc-structure. We can now try to apply the vanishing theorems of Section 9 to this particular setup:

p.text: Let (M,η,ξ,Φ,g) be a closed K-contact 5-manifold. If g has a transverse positive scalar curvature sT then all the invariants ⁢SW(Fξ,ρ) vanish.

para.p: If the metric g of the K-contact structure is Einstein, then the structure is in fact Sasakian and the metric has positive scalar curvature [3, 11, 12]. Also, whenever a K-contact manifold is locally symmetric or conformally flat, then it is Sasakian and has constant positive curvature (see [46, 53, 54]). We conclude that in all of the above cases all the basic Seiberg–Witten invariants vanish.
On the other hand, we can also apply the non-vanishing result of Theorem 38:

p.text: Let (M,η,ξ,Φ,g) be a compact 5-dimensional Sasakian manifold with ⩾dim⁢H+(F)2. Then =⁢SW(Fξ,ρ⁢can)±1.

para.p: Finally, we can combine the vanishing and non-vanishing results in order to obtain obstructions to metrics with positive scalar curvature or Einstein metrics.

p.text: Let (M,η,ξ,Φ,g) be a 5-dimensional compact Sasakian manifold with ⩾dim⁢H+(Fξ)2. Then M does not admit any bundle-like metric with respect to Fξ of positive transverse scalar curvature. In particular, (M,η) does not admit a Sasaki–Einstein metric.

para.p: When the Sasakian structure is regular (see [12, Definition 6.1.25]), it is clear that the basic Seiberg–Witten invariants are the same as the classical Seiberg–Witten invariants of the smooth 4-manifold given by the leaf space. This implies that the invariants really depend on the foliation and not only on the diffeomorphism type of the manifold as shown in the following simple example:

The 5-manifold ⁢8(×S2S3) admits two regular Sasakian structures: a negative one (see [12, Definition 7.5.24]) coming from a circle bundle over a Barlow surface (see [7] and [12, Example 10.4.6]) and a positive one coming from a circle bundle over a del Pezzo surface ⁢CP2#8¯⁢CP2 (see [12, Proposition 10.4.4]). In the first case, there are two non-vanishing classes corresponding to the canonical and the anti-canonical class (see for instance [47]), whilst in the second case all the basic Seiberg–Witten invariants vanish.

In the same vein, we can construct infinitely-many pairwise non-isotopic contact structures on diffeomorphic 5-manifolds from an infinite family of homeomorphic but pairwise non-diffeomorphic Kähler surfaces. The following example is taken from Hamilton’s paper [30]:
For each ⩾i0, we consider the minimal elliptic surface

Math.text: X _ i assign E * 4 _ (list@(3 + 2 * i, 5 + 2 * i))

para.p: obtained from the rational elliptic surface :=⁢E(1)⁢CP2#9¯⁢CP2 via fiber sums and logarithmic transformations [26]. The Xi are simply-connected spin 4-manifolds with Betti numbers =⁢b2(Xi)46 and =⁢b2+(Xi)7. So, they are homeomorphic by Freedman’s classification [22]. On the other hand, we can use classical Seiberg–Witten theory to show that they are pairwise non-diffeomorphic. Indeed, the number of ⁢Spinc-structures with non-zero Seiberg–Witten invariant is different for each Xi as it equals ⁢3(+3⁢2i)(+5⁢2i) [26].

If we build a regular circle bundle over each of the Xi, we can use Barden’s classification of simply-connected 5-manifolds to deduce that the total space is diffeomorphic to ×⁢#45S2S3 for each of the Xi. The Boothby–Wang construction associates to each of the (integral) symplectic structures of the elliptic surfaces Mi a contact structure on the circle bundle ×⁢#45S2S3 We get a regular Sasakian structure on the 5-manifold, i.e. a taut transversally Kähler foliation. The basic Seiberg–Witten invariants reduce once more to the classical Seiberg–Witten invariants on the base manifold Xi. Suppose there were two isotopic contact structures Di and Dj. By Gray’s stability theorem, there is a global diffeomorphism φ of the 5-manifold such that =⁢φ*(Dj)Di This induces a cobordism on the moduli space of basic Seiberg–Witten solutions. We arrive at a contradiction because the invariants are different.

Note that, as opposed to Hamilton, we did not need to use contact homology for distinguishing the non-isotopic contact structures. Instead, we merely used the fact that, for a taut regular foliation, the basic Seiberg–Witten invariants descend to the classical 4-dimensional invariants.

On a closed simply-connected 5-manifold, the space of ⁢Spinc-structures is isomorphic to the space of homotopy classes of almost-contact structures. Whilst this isomorphism is not canonical in general, it becomes so on a contact metric manifold. We conclude that on a closed simply-connected K-contact 5-manifold (M,η,ξ,Φ,g), the basic Seiberg–Witten map may be interpreted as a map eating homotopy classes of almost-contact structures instead of ⁢Spinc-structures:

Math.text: S * W * F _ xi colon set@([homotopy classes of almost-contact structures]) rightarrow Z

para.p: Furthermore, Geiges showed that every homotopy class of almost contact structures contains at least one contact structure [24].
